thread.title: The Team Up Next, and Mets History
thread.title_full: The Team Up Next, and Mets History - The New York Times

author: Jay Schreiber
title: The Team Up Next, and Mets History
text:
Not all interleague matchups are created equal. Over the last two decades, the Mets have faced the Yankees on 104 occasions in the regular season, the Boston Red Sox 24 times and the Kansas City Royals, their possible World Series opponent, just nine.
In fact, there is only one team the Mets have met less often than the Royals since interleague baseball began in 1997, and that is the Chicago White Sox, who have played the Mets just seven times.
The scarcity of Royals-Mets matchups will add a bit of intrigue to the World Series if they do meet up. The teams played in 2013, when the Royals took two of three games at Citi Field; in 2004, when the Royals won two of three at Kauffman Stadium; and in 2002, when the Mets took two of three at Shea Stadium. That means each team has played just one series in the other’s current stadium.
Continue reading the main story Related Coverage Sorry, Jose, This Joe Batt Came First OCT. 23, 2015 Even in the Language of 1908, the Cubs Come Up Losers OCT. 22, 2015 Mets 8, Cubs 3: Mets, Team of Big Shoulders, Sweep Cubs to Reach World Series OCT. 21, 2015 For the Mets, Pennies Saved Add Up to a Pennant Earned OCT. 22, 2015 After a Sweep, the World Series Is Anything but a Breeze OCT. 22, 2015 As for the Toronto Blue Jays, the Mets’ other possible opponents, the teams have met 25 times over the years, with the Mets winning 17 and the Blue Jays winning eight. Their last matchup came in mid-June this season, when the Mets won two games at Citi Field and the Blue Jays responded by winning the two games at Rogers Centre.
Continue reading the main story Sports Newsletter Get the big sports news, highlights and analysis from Times journalists, with distinctive takes on games and some behind-the-scenes surprises, delivered to your inbox every week.
The Blue Jays are one of only two teams in baseball that still use artificial turf. The other is the Tampa Bay Rays, who play at Tropicana Field in St. Petersburg, Fla. The Mets played there this season, too, losing two of three to the Rays. So at least the Mets have had some recent experience on artificial turf, if that does end up being a factor in the Series.
